name: Copper(II) nitrate
desc: Copper(II) nitrate, Cu(NO3)2, is an inorganic compound that forms a blue crystalline solid. Anhydrous copper nitrate forms deep blue-green crystals and sublimes in a vacuum at 150-200 °C. Copper nitrate also occurs as five different hydrates, the most common ones being the trihydrate and hexahydrate. These materials are more commonly encountered in commerce than in the laboratory.
Solubility in water:
trihydrate:[1]
381 g/100 mL (40 °C)
666 g/100 mL (80 °C)
hexahydrate:[1]
243.7 g/100 mL (80 °C)
Solubility: hydrates very soluble in ethanol, ammonia, water; insoluble in ethyl acetate
standard state:
